FuncDescriptionShort: Calculating auto-correlation and auto-covariance of a time series
FuncDescriptionLong: The auto-covariance and auto-correlation function compute how a time series covaries or correlates with itself, when delayed by a particular lag
Example:For a lag equal to 1, we calculate the covariance or correlation between time series Yt  and time series Yt-1
for lag equal to 2, we calculate the covariance or correlation between time series Yt  and time series Yt-2

Input.Description: Specifies a series that is one dimensional array passed as an input to the function.

Description: Specifies the result in an ART table
Output.LangName: data or object or newdata or ... --> Langauges team can work with UAF team to come up with this field

Params.Name: MAXLAGS
Description: Maximum number of lags at which to calculate the autocorrelation/autocovariance.
Default is 10*log10(N) where N is the number of observations.
Automatically limited to one less than the number of observations in the series.
If the numLags value specified by the user exceeds this limit, the user input value is ignored and replaced with the system defined max value.

Params.Name: FUNC_TYPE
Description: Specifies whether it is a auto-correlation or auto-covariance function.
0 means execute the auto-correlation function.  1 means execute the auto-covariance function

Params.Name: UNBIASED
Description: If 0, then denominator for autocovariance is n-k (Jenkins & Watts formula)
otherwise if 1, denominator for autocovariance is n (Box & Jenkins formula).

Params.Name: DEMEAN
Description: If 1 (default), then subtract the mean x from each element of x, as specified in the formulas for autocorrelation or autocovariance.
If 0, then we do NOT do the subtraction on each element before computing the autocorrelation or autocovariance.

Params.Name: QSTAT
Description: 1 means provide Ljung-Box q statistic for each autocorrelation coefficient.
0 (default) means do not provide.   Requesting a QSTAT results in a QSTATVAL and PVALUE set of result columns being returned.

Params.Name: ALPHA
Description: If a non-zero positive number is given, the confidence intervals for the given level are returned.
For example, if alpha=.05 meaning the 95% level , then confidence intervals are returned where the standard deviation is computed according to Bartlettâ€™s formula.
Passing in a positive number results in a CONFINT result column being returned
